Reviews.Title: A good drive for the PS4 and a decent price too.
Reviews.Author: Chuck Bittner "Disabled comedian & gamer!"
Reviews.Content: If you're someone like me and wants to upgrade their PlayStation 4 from its 500GB hard drive to something more spacious this drive is a good choice. I looked around the Internet this was the best price going (at the time of writing this the price was $124). With PlayStation 4 games weighing in at near 30GB+ for a lot of games and hard drive the size will eventually be a must upgrade. And if you're interested in upgrading your PlayStation hard drive it's a pretty straightforward process.UPGRADING YOUR PS4 TAKE LESS THAN 30 minutes - You need to download the firmware from Sony*.Step 1: remove the gloss section of your PS4.  It's the part above the Blu-Ray slot.Step 2: Remove the 500gb drive (requires 1 screw to be removed) Unscrew the 4 screws holding the drive in the cage.Step 3: Put the PS4 back together.Step 4: Insert your usb flash drive into the PS4 usb slot.Step 5: Press and hold the power button on the PS4 for 8-10 seconds.Step 6: Choose the bottom selection (I believe it's number 10) Reinstall firmware.Step 7: That's it you are done only about 30 minutes and done.*One thing you need if you're replacing a hard drive on the PlayStation is the latest firmware update from Sony's website and you need a 1 GB plus thumb drive formatted in fat32. And you just set up your thumb drive with a folder called PS4 an inside that folder another one called UPDATE. Then inside the update folder you place the firmware.And that's it super easy to do takes no time in this drive efficiently doubles your storage space and drastically increases your load speed for games.Thanks for reading if you have a questions just ask them.Here are the steps for the PlayStation 31. Unscrew the drive cover2. Pull out the old hard drive3. Remove the drive from the drive bracket and insert your new hard drive.4. Put it back into your PlayStation and put the screw in place.5. Install the operating system from a flash or USB hard drive.Now you will need to get the PlayStation operating system from Sony before you attempt a hard drive replacement but it's pretty simple and straightforward and one of the best selling points of the Sony PlayStation.Thanks readingPS personally I went with a 1TB 72000rpm drive in my PS4.

Reviews.Title: It works
Reviews.Author: Welly WU
Reviews.Content: I have a System76 Lemur Ultra Thin (lemu4) notebook PC and I installed Lubuntu 13.04 64 bit GNU/Linux on this new Hitachi Travelstar 5K1500 laptop hard disk drive. It works just like a conventional 5,400 RPM laptop hard disk drive. It gives me up to 1.50 terabytes of available storage capacity. I needed this to replace a Crucial m4 SATA-3 128.00 gigabyte solid state disk. Now, I can store my entire media library with several hundreds of gigabytes of available disk space left over. It's faster than my Toshiba 1 terabyte 5,400 RPM hard disk drive which is only SATA-2 with 8 MB of cache. So far, it seems to be reliable and it's a tremendous advantage to have a GNU/Linux laptop with 1.50 terabytes of storage capacity. I would recommend it to others thinking about upgrading their older notebook PCs who are looking for the highest capacity laptop hard disk drive currently available. You'll need a laptop with at least a single drive bay that can fit the standard 2.5" 9.5 mm laptop hard disk drive. This won't work with Intel Ultrabooks that require the 7 mm laptop disk drives so do be sure to check your PC specifications. It would work well with almost any desktop operating system. It's not as fast as a 7,200 RPM laptop hard disk drive, but those types of disk drives are being phased out of the market gradually. A 5,400 RPM hard disk drive is a good choice if you want to conserve on your laptop's battery life and this Hitachi Travelstar 5K1500 consumes low energy while in usage. I probably extended my battery life by another 12 minutes.

In other words, one file has about 300mb (update), while the correct file has about 800mb (operating system). You only need the 800mb file.

Reviews.Title: MIGHT BE SLOW ON A NOTEBOOK OR LAPTOP BUT MY PS4 SYSTEM IS LOVING IT!
Reviews.Author: THE AUTISTIC WEREWOLF "Wolf"
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased the HGST Travelstar 5K1500 1.5TB 2.5-Inch Mobile 5400 RPM hard drive to expand the dinky little 500 GB hard drive that came standard with my second PS4. I'm not a big time gamer so I hardly need all the space. My brother wanted me to buy this just because; it have more space. I told my brother once that you should always buy the biggest hard drive you can afford for his computer so I gave in and did so.This HGST Travelstar 5K1500 1.5TB 2.5-Inch Mobile 5400 RPM hard drive installed with no issues at all. The PS4 seems to almost be made to accommodate this drive upgrade.  Just make sure you have the 872 GB version of the PS4*******.PUP Update file placed on a USB device that is formated in the Fat 32 file system. The The 312 MB PS4*****.PUP update file does not have the initialization protocols needed to install the update on a drive that has never been used in a PS4 unit.Make things easy on yourself use a USB storage drive with 8 0r so GIGABYTES on it. Your PS4 recognizes the Fat 32 file system. The Fat 32 file system is on most Microsoft Windows computers in the Format Windlows Explorer Menu.  Go to your Windows Explorer highlight your USB storage device.  Right mouse click and select FORMAT from the menu shown. Select Fat32 file system from the options provided.  Format the USB drive as fat 32 file system. Create folders as instructed by PS4 site and place the PS4*****.PUP file in the folder indicated. Install drive in PS4 console swaping out the old hard drive. With this hard drive installed in the PS4 place the USB device containing your FAT32 formated drive and the PS$ file structure awith its PS$******.PUP file in the USB port os your PS4 and turn it on.Make sure your controller is connceted to your PS$ by its wire since your PS4 is pretty much brain dead without an operating system. Press the PS button on your controller when instructed and the menu's will likely guide you through the rest of the process of initializing and setting up your new huge new 1.5 drive. Now do not be surprised when you have 1.3 TB showing on tour system you were not cheated.  Space is taken up by the PS4 operating system and disk management eats up some space too.  You will have over 1 TB of usable space with the successful install of this drive and thats the best thing. I've had no issues with this drive and found it awesome.

Reviews.Content: got this for my PS4.. and so far.. it has worked perfectly!!I haven't compared load times vs the original (heck it might be the same specs but just bigger storage). but if you are looking for more space with a tested HD.. this one I can say so far it's worked....go online and check for method to exchange, it's pretty easy.... but here are just a few pointers...You need a USB that fits into the PS4 with at least 1 GB.. download the file that is like 800 plus MB (not the one that is 400)... the bigger one is the one for hard drive exchange.. I found a Hard Drive Enclosure, that lets you put your hard drive into a metal case and use as an external (link below)... you will have to know how to format the HD and all that but you can put it to good use.. not sure if you can format it for future use on the Xbox One, because it's a 2.0 USB.. but  at least you have it and you can use it with a computer :)http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E362W9O/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc;=1

Reviews.Title: 3X the space for my PS4
Reviews.Author: fatguyinalilcoat "cartman_98"
Reviews.Content: This is the largest drive you can get till the Samsung 2TB speedstar comes out later this year. Works great and the instructions are easy to swap out the Playstation 4's drive. If you have saved game data, you can save it to a USB thumb drive. But you will need 2 in the case of this then, one for the saved data and one for the Installation of the Playstation OS on the new Hard drive you put in. I have listed both below.Transferring save data below:--------------------------------------------From Sony's Site-----------------------------------------------------------------***********************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************Before replacing, transferring or disposing of your PS4(tm) system, delete your Sony Entertainment Network account and other information from the PS4(tm) system in advance by performing the following procedures. This helps to protect your personal information and helps to prevent its unauthorized use by third parties.Backing up saved data for gamesCopy saved data that is stored on your PS4(tm) system to a USB storage device as necessary. You can copy saved data with  (Settings) > [Application Saved Data Management] > [Saved Data in System Storage] > [Copy to USB Storage Device].To use this feature, you must sign in to PSNSM.If you subscribe to PlayStation®Plus, you can upload saved data to online storage. For details, see "Subscribing to PlayStation®Plus".Deactivating a systemIf you activated the system as your primary PS4(tm) system, deactivate it before transferring or disposing of it. You cannot deactivate the system after you have transferred or disposed of it. Deactivate the system under  (Settings) > [PSNSM] > [Activate as Your Primary PS4].If multiple users have activated the system as their primary PS4(tm) system, deactivate it for each user.Initializing the PS4(tm) systemDuring initialization, the PS4(tm) system settings are restored to their defaults, and all users and their data saved on the PS4(tm) system are deleted. Initialize the system under  (Settings) > [Initialization] > [Initialize PS4] > [Full].Installing the Operating system on the upgraded HDD:----------------------------------From Sony's Site---------------------------------------------*******************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************Replace the hard disk driveMake sure the PS4 it turned completely off. When the power indicator is off, the system is completely off. If the power indicator is lit up in orange, the system is in standby mode. Exit standby mode.Unplug the AC power cord, and then disconnect the other cables from the system.For safety reasons, remove the plug for AC power cord from the electrical outlet, and then detach the other cables.Slide the HDD bay cover in the direction of the arrow to remove it.Remove the HDD.Remove the screw.Pull the HDD toward the front of the system to remove it.Using a phillips screwdriver, remove the screws (four places).Do not remove the rubber inserts from the screw holes.Place the replacement HDD on the mounting bracket for the PS4(tm) system's HDD, and then attach using the screws (four places).Do not over-tighten the screws.Attach the HDD to the system using the screw.Be sure to fully insert the HDD in the HDD bay.If you lose the HDD bay cover, screws, mounting bracket, or any other parts, contact technical support for assistance.Install the system softwareAfter the HDD has been replaced, the system software must be reinstalled. Using a computer, save a system software update file for reinstallation to a USB storage device. (1GB free space)Click here for instructions regarding downloading and performing the reinstallation update.Copying backed up saved data for games to the PS4(tm) systemYou can copy saved data from a USB storage device to the PS4(tm) system by performing the following steps.Connect a USB storage device to the system.Select (Settings) from the function screen.Select [Application Saved Data Management] > [Saved Data on USB Storage Device] > [Copy to System Storage].Select a title.Press X to add a checkmark in the checkbox for the saved data you want to copy, and then select [Copy].You must be signed in with the same PSNSM account used when you first copied the saved data.If you backed up your saved games to the cloud using PlayStation Plus, you can safely restore them nowhope this helps. =)

Reviews.Title: Extremely fast delivery, good performance
Reviews.Author: Balaji Ramanathan "balajithegreat"
Reviews.Content: The item was shipped and delivered within 2 days of placing my order (I in fact had to go back to my order and verify that I had chosen free shipping rather than signed up unknowingly for Amazon Prime or something like that).  It came well packaged in a box within a box, with good cushioning and support.  The disk itself is in a waterproof plastic package with some silica gel inside for extra protection from moisture.Once I got my old hard drive out from my laptop, it was very simple to slot this in place and secure it with screws.  The hard drive does not come with any caddy of any sort, and my laptop does not require any.  After that it was simply a matter of reimaging it with the factory image, and we were off to the races.I don't know what the format of the laptop is as delivered because I immediately installed it in my laptop and reformatted it as part of the imaging process.  I ran a full disk check on it (including a surface check), and it came back with no bad sectors or other problems.My only concern with the disk is that after the reimaging, the disk got partitioned into 4 partitions, including a 35GB partition that is unallocated.  My previous hard disk had only 3 partitions on it.  I have no idea where this 4th partition came from, and since it is in the middle of the disk (after a hidden partition and the system recovery partition, but before the main C: partition), I can't easily add this space to my main partition.  So, it is basically 35GB of wasted space.  Given its capacity, this is not a big loss, so I am not going to take away any stars for this (and it may not even have had anything to do with the disk to begin with, but more to do with my factory image).The disk, as far as I can tell, has 512-byte sectors, not the new AFD 4K sectors, so I didn't have to do anything special in Windows 7 64-bit for it to work without any problems.  As for transfer speeds, it is only a 5400-rpm disk, so it is not blazing fast, but it is fast enough for my purposes.  Because of the high data density of the disk, and the 3-platter design, which allows for 2 more heads to participate in parallel data reads and writes than a typical 2-platter disk allows, transfer speeds are quite fast (I did a full disk image of the 1.5TB disk at 1.7GB/min, taking a total of about 14.5 hours using Clonezilla).

Reviews.Title: Worst drive I've purchased so far
Reviews.Author: BackendFiller
Reviews.Content: I'm an IT Professional professional and purchase new drives on a regular basis. Unfortunately, this drive was good for about 1 hour, once finished formatting the drive it would no longer spin up. I was intrigued by the large capacity on a 2.5" drive that i could install into my mac, but very disappointed when i could not even install the operating system on it; temporarily running the OS off a 64GB flash drive until my new WD 1TB drive comes in.I have run external drive tests on the drive as well and it still will not power on. Unfortunately, i had to have the drive "reshipped" to another location and cannot ship it back.
